title.value: Preclinical-to-clinical Anti-cancer Drug Response Prediction and Biomarker Identification Using TINDL
title.justification: The title explicitly states the main focus and contribution of the paper, which is the development of the TINDL framework for drug response prediction and biomarker identification.
title.quote: Here, we developed a deep learning framework called TINDL, completely trained on preclinical cancer cell lines (CCLs), to predict the response of cancer patients to different treatments.

extractions.description: The paper introduces TINDL, a deep learning framework developed to predict the anti-cancer drug response and identify biomarkers using preclinical cancer cell lines. TINDL employs a tissue-informed normalization to account for tissue and cancer type variations and addresses statistical discrepancies between cell lines and patient tumors. The framework enhances prediction accuracy and facilitates identification of predictive biomarkers, validated through experiments and comparison with existing models.

type.justification: The paper involves experimentation with a deep learning framework (TINDL) to predict drug responses and validate its effectiveness through comparisons and experiments.
type.quote: Using data from two large databases of CCLs and cancer tumors, we showed that this model can distinguish between sensitive and resistant tumors for 10 (out of 14) drugs, outperforming various other machine learning models.

name.justification: The primary focus of the research is on predicting the response of cancer patients to treatments and identifying cancer drug response biomarkers.
name.quote: Prediction of the response of cancer patients to different treatments and identification of biomarkers of drug response are two major goals of individualized medicine.

name.justification: The paper utilizes bioinformatics methods and databases such as the Genomics of Drug Sensitivity in Cancer (GDSC) and The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA).
name.quote: Focusing on drugs shared between the Genomics of Drug Sensitivity in Cancer (GDSC) and TCGA, we showed that TINDL can distinguish between the sensitive and resistant patients.

name.justification: The paper involves developing and leveraging machine learning models, including deep learning techniques, for cancer research.
name.quote: Here, we developed a deep learning framework called TINDL, completely trained on preclinical cancer cell lines (CCLs), to predict the response of cancer patients to different treatments.

name.justification: The research utilizes large datasets from genomic studies and focuses on gene expression profiles to predict drug responses.
name.quote: On the other hand, large databases of molecular profiles of hundreds of in vitro cancer cell lines (CCLs) and their response to hundreds of drugs have enabled development of various ML algorithms for prediction of drug response.

name.justification: The study is related to drug response prediction, which falls under pharmacogenomics.
name.quote: A community effort to assess and improve drug sensitivity prediction algorithms is part of pharmacogenomics research.

name.justification: The paper presents TINDL as the main model, developed and tested within the scope of the research.
name.quote: Here, we developed a deep learning framework called TINDL, completely trained on preclinical cancer cell lines (CCLs), to predict the response of cancer patients to different treatments.

is_contributed.justification: The model TINDL is newly developed and presented in this paper as a contribution to the field.
is_contributed.quote: Unlike methods mentioned above, TINDL requires normalization of only test samples, and as a result retraining of the model is not necessary for new test samples.

is_executed.justification: TINDL was executed and tested as part of the research to demonstrate its effectiveness.
is_executed.quote: Using data from two large databases of CCLs and cancer tumors, we showed that this model can distinguish between sensitive and resistant tumors for 10 (out of 14) drugs, outperforming various other machine learning models.

is_compared.justification: TINDL was compared with other machine learning models in terms of performance.
is_compared.quote: TINDL can distinguish between sensitive and resistant patients for 10 (out of 14) drugs, improving the performance of other methods, including our previous work, tissue-guided least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (TG-LASSO).

referenced_paper_title.justification: There is no prior referenced paper title for TINDL as it is newly introduced in this research.

name.value: Genomics of Drug Sensitivity in Cancer (GDSC)
name.justification: The GDSC is one of the datasets used for training and evaluating TINDL's performance.
name.quote: We showed that TINDL can distinguish between the sensitive and resistant patients for 10 (out of 14) drugs, focusing on drugs shared between the Genomics of Drug Sensitivity in Cancer (GDSC) and TCGA.

referenced_paper_title.value: Genomics of Drug Sensitivity in Cancer (GDSC): a resource for therapeutic biomarker discovery in cancer cells.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is referenced in the context of previous use as a source of therapeutic biomarker data.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Genomics of Drug Sensitivity in Cancer (GDSC): a resource for therapeutic biomarker discovery in cancer cells.

name.justification: TCGA is used in the paper to test the model predictions for clinical samples.
name.quote: Focusing on drugs shared between the Genomics of Drug Sensitivity in Cancer (GDSC) and TCGA, we showed that TINDL can distinguish...

referenced_paper_title.value: The Cancer Genome Atlas Pan-Cancer analysis project.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference is to the broader TCGA project that compiles cancer genomic data used in the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The Cancer Genome Atlas Pan-Cancer analysis project.

name.justification: CXPlain is used as a method to provide explanations of prediction made by the TINDL model in the study.
name.quote: In the second phase of TINDL, we used CXPlain as the explainer to assign a contribution score to each gene in each sample.

referenced_paper_title.value: CXPlain: causal explanations for model interpretation under uncertainty.
referenced_paper_title.justification: CXPlain is cited in the context of providing interpretability for deep learning models used in this study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: CXPlain: causal explanations for model interpretation under uncertainty.
